title: No Corrections: Feb. 19, 2024
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Feb. 19, 2024.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Alan Feuer
title: Ex-Informant Accused of Lying About Bidens Said He Had Russian Contacts
description: Federal prosecutors portrayed the former informant, Alexander Smirnov, 43, as a serial liar incapable of telling the truth about even the most basic details of his own life.
content: A former F.B.I. informant accused of making false bribery claims about President Biden and his son Hunter — which were widely publicized by Republicans — claimed to have been fed information by Russian intelligence, according to a court filing on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Fencing Option
description: Jeffrey Martinovic points out the obvious.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: What the Ukraine Aid Debate Is Really About
description: Two key presumptions are at the heart of the debate over Ukraine vs. Taiwan.
content: Over the weekend Senator J.D. Vance of Ohio went to the Munich Security Conference to play an unpopular part — a spokesman, at a gathering of the Western foreign policy establishment, for the populist critique of American support for Ukraine’s war effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: Haley Says ‘Embryos, to Me, Are Babies,’ in Response to Alabama Court Ruling
description: The former South Carolina governor has walked a fine line on reproductive medicine during the Republican presidential primary.
content: Nikki Haley told NBC News on Wednesday that she believed that embryos created through in vitro fertilization were “babies,” after the Alabama Supreme Court on Friday delivered a major ruling that raised legal questions about reproductive medicine and fertility care.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Where Hostage Families and Supporters Gather, for Solace and Protest
description: A plaza in Tel Aviv has become a home away from home. “If I don’t know what to do, I come here,” one relative said.
content: A week after Hamas-led terrorists stormed his kibbutz and kidnapped his wife and three young children, Avihai Brodutch planted himself on the sidewalk in front of army headquarters in Tel Aviv holding a sign scrawled with the words “My family’s in Gaza,” and said he would not budge until they were brought home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Thursday Briefing: U.S. Warnings About a Russian Space Weapon
description: Also, a blow to Pakistan’s military and Niue’s fight for the .nu domain.
content: U.S. intelligence agencies have told their closest European allies that if Russia is going to launch a nuclear weapon into orbit, it will probably do so this year. But, they warned, it might instead launch a harmless “dummy” warhead to leave the West guessing about its capabilities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: ‘Mister Organ,’ ‘Destroyer’ and More Streaming Gems
description: Con artists and ghost stories are among our recommendations from the subscription streaming services this month.
content: A unique horror omnibus, an existentialist supernatural story, and atypical star turns are among our recommendations from the subscription streaming services this month, along with some essential background viewing for one of this year’s Oscar nominees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Don Clark
title: Nvidia Says Growth Will Continue as A.I. Hits ‘Tipping Point’
description: The A.I. chip maker’s revenue more than tripled, and profits rose ninefold. It also projected that its revenue would more than triple again.
content: Nvidia, the kingpin of chips powering artificial intelligence, on Wednesday released quarterly financial results that reinforced how the company has become one of the biggest winners of the artificial intelligence boom, and it said demand for its products would fuel continued sales growth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith and Tariq Panja
title: Bowing to Fan Revolt, German Soccer Rejects $1 Billion Investment
description: A proposed marketing partnership with a private equity firm was abandoned after weeks of protests that disrupted matches across the country.
content: Germany’s soccer fans had thrown everything they could at the problem, often in a quite literal sense: At various points over the last few weeks, they protested the specter of a private equity giant’s taking a stake in the country’s domestic league by raining tennis balls, chocolate coins and even marbles onto fields across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rhonda Garelick
title: At 74, Miuccia Prada Makes an Unexpected Vogue Cover Model
description: Mrs. Prada became a legend in fashion for having invented a unique, counterintuitive aesthetic, at once thought-provoking and alluring.
content: Throughout Vogue’s history, its typical cover stars have included a parade of youthful beauties: models, actresses, celebrities, the occasional stunning athlete and, once in a while, a politician or first lady — all glammed to the max.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember and Niraj Chokshi
title: Boeing 737 Max Official Is Out as Questions Linger on Mishap
description: The head of the factory making Max jets is leaving the company as it faces scrutiny of an incident that left a hole in a plane’s fuselage in flight.
content: Boeing said on Wednesday that it was shaking up the leadership in its commercial airplanes unit after a harrowing incident last month during which a piece fell off a 737 Max 9 jet in flight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: Are People Who Read Magazines Without Paying ‘Stealing’ Their Content?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on bookstore etiquette.
content: At the local Barnes & Noble, the in-store coffee shop is next to the vast selection of magazines for sale. Many coffee drinkers grab multiple magazines and take them to their table with their coffee and read them. After coffee, most, but not all, put the magazines back in the racks without paying for them. They are “stealing” content that is meant to be purchased. Is this a form of shoplifting? — Name Withheld
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: A New Orleans Man Wants His Opossum Back. Thousands Have Joined His Plea.
description: The much-loved marsupial, Saffron, was known to frequent the French Quarter with his owner. A friend started a petition for the opossum’s return after state wildlife authorities seized him this month.
content: A man in New Orleans lonesome for an opossum named Saffron, whom he had raised as a pet and dressed in a colorful sweater, is appealing to authorities to return the animal, which was taken from him by state wildlife officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: Sara Mearns and Jamar Roberts to Be Resident Artists at Vail
description: The summer’s Vail Dance Festival features Mearns, the New York City Ballet star, and the choreographer Roberts.
content: Fans of the intrepid New York City Ballet principal Sara Mearns and of the distinguished choreographer Jamar Roberts might want to mark their calendars. This year, they will be artists in residence at the Vail Dance Festival. Both will teach master classes and participate in community events, and Mearns will perform in a range of works, including debuts in George Balanchine’s “Elegie” and a new piece by Roberts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Russian Forces Press On With Attacks in Southern Ukraine
description: The assaults on the village of Robotyne, which come at the same time as successful attacks in the east, are designed to pressure Ukrainian troops across the front line, analysts say.
content: Russian forces in recent days have launched multiple attacks around the southern Ukrainian village of Robotyne, military officials and experts said, targeting land hard-won by Ukraine in a rare success of its counteroffensive last summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: ‘Hotel California’ Trial Centers on Handwritten Eagles Lyrics
description: Three men face charges in Manhattan that they trafficked in classic rock ephemera: notes that contained early versions of Eagles hits.
content: In the late 1970s, a writer working on a book about the Eagles that would never be published obtained 100-odd pages of notes and lyrics related to the multiplatinum album “Hotel California.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Chips Away at Student Loan Debt, Bit by Bit, Amid High Expectations
description: The president announced another $1.2 billion in forgiveness, bringing the total canceled to $138 billion. But the piecemeal efforts have garnered him little praise.
content: After the Supreme Court struck down President Biden’s plan to cancel billions of dollars in student loan debt, borrowers wondered how he would make good on his promise to tackle debt burdening millions of Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer
title: Here’s Where Biden’s Climate Law Is Working, and Where It’s Falling Short
description: Electric vehicles are booming as expected, a new analysis found, but renewable power isn’t growing as quickly as hoped.
content: A year and a half after President Biden signed into law a sweeping bill to tackle climate change, sales of electric vehicles have largely boomed in line with expectations, according to a new analysis by three groups tracking the impact of the law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Sidney Powell and Other Trump-Aligned Lawyers Will Face Legal Penalties
description: The Supreme Court declined to take up an appeal by a group of lawyers who challenged the 2020 election results in Michigan.
content: Sidney Powell, L. Lin Wood and several other lawyers who advanced former President Donald J. Trump’s false claims of a stolen election will face legal penalties after the Supreme Court declined to take up their appeal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Armorer Who Loaded Gun in Alec Baldwin Shooting Faces Trial: What to Know
description: The armorer, Hannah Gutierrez-Reed, is charged with involuntary manslaughter in the fatal shooting of a cinematographer on the set of the film “Rust.” She has pleaded not guilty.
content: The armorer who loaded the gun that Alec Baldwin was rehearsing with on a film set in 2021 when it fired a live round and killed the movie’s cinematographer is heading to trial in New Mexico this week on a charge of involuntary manslaughter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Key Races to Watch in California’s March 5 Primary
description: Voters will choose nominees for president and weigh in on state and local contests that could have big ramifications.
content: Primary season is officially underway for the 22 million registered voters in California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: A Missing Scottish Trophy Will Be Awarded Again After 95 Years
description: Fancy a chance to claim the Rose Bowl? Get really good at carrying stones.
content: At a traditional Scottish Highland Games, fit athletes engage in rigorous pursuits like caber-tossing, hammer-throwing and stone-carrying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: How to Have Your First Anniversary in Four Years
description: Leap day weddings hold a certain allure for some couples.
content: After getting engaged in November, Claire Engstrom, 33, a registered nurse in Atlanta, proposed an idea to her fiancée: Why not get married on Feb. 29? Known as leap day, it is the date added to the end of February every four years to keep the calendar aligned with the seasons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: John Avlon, CNN Commentator, Enters Race for Long Island Swing Seat
description: Mr. Avlon, a Democrat who helped found the centrist political group No Labels, is seeking to unseat the Republican incumbent, Representative Nick LaLota.
content: John Avlon, a Democrat and former CNN political analyst, announced on Wednesday that he would enter a crowded congressional primary to try to flip a Republican-held swing seat on Long Island.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Conor Dougherty
title: What Is Your Housing Situation? We Want to Hear From You.
description: A Times housing reporter wants to learn more about the pressures of rising housing costs and how they have affected your community and family.
content: “No society can be fully understood apart from the residences of its members.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: How Involved Do You Expect Your Parents to Be in Your Adult Life?
description: New surveys show that many parents play a big role in their adult children’s lives — and that both parties seem happy with the arrangement. Would you welcome it?
content: When you imagine adulthood, do you picture your parents still playing a big role in your life? Or do you hope to be largely self-sufficient?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Biden’s Fund-Raising Edge, and Ukrainian Troops Are Feared Missing
description: Plus, the embryo ruling shaking doctors and patients.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Nikki Haley Can’t Count on South Carolina’s Newcomers for Help
description: Nearly 10 percent of South Carolina voters were not in the state when Nikki Haley left office in 2017, and many newcomers brought with them an affection for Donald Trump.
content: After Nikki Haley’s disappointing finishes in Iowa and New Hampshire earlier this year, she promised she would storm back in the next big Republican primary to deliver “a great day in South Carolina,” the state where she was born and raised and where she occupied the governor’s mansion for six years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Biden Fund-Raising Outpaces Trump, Whose Legal Bills Are Weighing Him Down
description: Federal filings show the president’s re-election campaign had nearly double the cash on hand of his Republican rival at the end of January.
content: President Biden’s re-election campaign ended January with nearly $56 million on hand, extending his cash advantage over former President Donald J. Trump, whose campaign had about $30 million available at the end of the month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: Man Arrested in Arizona Is Suspected in Manhattan Hotel Homicide
description: The man was arrested after what the police said were other attacks on other women. They are investigating to see whether more cases might be linked to him.
content: At the SoHo 54 Hotel in Manhattan this month, a man and woman argued about how long he would be allowed to stay in room 1109.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: Silicon Valley Venture Capitalists Are Breaking Up With China
description: Under intensifying scrutiny from U.S. lawmakers, top firms have pulled back from investing in Chinese start-ups.
content: DCM Ventures, a Silicon Valley venture capital firm, began investing in China’s start-ups in 1999. The move reaped such blockbuster returns that in 2021, DCM said it planned to “double down” on its strategy of investing in China, the United States and Japan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: $89 Million Can’t Fix Her Mistakes
description: After a dramatic rise in business and society, the art-world mogul Louise Blouin finds herself unloading a Hamptons dream home in bankruptcy court.
content: “I haven’t made many mistakes,” Louise Blouin said soon after her compound in the Hamptons was sold out from under her in a bankruptcy auction. “You can’t judge someone because they have an issue once in their life. I’m sure Steve Jobs didn’t have a perfect track record.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: Denis Villeneuve and Timothée Chalamet: ‘Dune’ Dynasty
description: With “Part Two” hitting theaters, they discuss another potential sequel, the impossible quest for onscreen perfection and those infamous popcorn buckets.
content: The director Denis Villeneuve and the actor Timothée Chalamet bound into the room talking at, and over, each other in rapid French. Villeneuve is from Quebec; Chalamet was born in New York City but has dual American and French citizenship. Together, they’re a dynamic tag team dressed near-identically in head-to-toe black, although Chalamet’s shiny leather layers have more swagger. The topic of the day is galactic genocide and dubious messiahs, central themes in “Dune: Part Two,” the second installment of their cerebral space epic based on the 1965 novel by Frank Herbert. Yet, the pair are prone to giggle fits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: A British Nuclear Missile Test Fails, Again
description: An unarmed Trident missile splashed into the sea close to its launch site, the U.K. government confirmed on Wednesday, fueling scrutiny of the state of Britain’s nuclear deterrent.
content: The British government confirmed on Wednesday that the test launch of an unarmed Trident missile from a Royal Navy submarine last month had failed, raising questions about the state of Britain’s nuclear deterrence capability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser and Adam Goldman
title: Man Extradited to U.S. in Suspected Iranian Plot to Kill Activist
description: The man, a citizen of Georgia, and three others were charged with planning to assassinate Masih Alinejad, an Iranian American human rights activist in Brooklyn and a critic of Iran.
content: A man charged with participating in a plot hatched in Iran to assassinate Masih Alinejad, an Iranian American human rights activist and a sharp critic of Iran’s repression of women, has been extradited to the United States, American authorities said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Betts
title: After Ruling, University of Alabama at Birmingham Health System Pauses I.V.F. Procedures
description: The U.A.B. system said it was worried about potential criminal prosecutions after Alabama’s Supreme Court ruled that frozen embryos should be considered children.
content: The University of Alabama at Birmingham health system announced on Wednesday that it was pausing in vitro fertilization treatments as it evaluated the Alabama Supreme Court’s ruling that frozen embryos should be considered children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Wednesday Briefing
description: Ukrainian troops are feared missing or captured.
content: Hundreds of Ukrainian troops may have been captured by Russian forces during Ukraine’s chaotic retreat from the eastern city of Avdiivka, according to senior Western officials and soldiers fighting for Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: In Love? Share Screenshots of Your First Digital Exchanges
description: How did your relationship go from “hey” to heartfelt? We want to see the messages that started it all — and hear about what happened next.
content: Not long ago, nearly every initial conversation with a potential romantic partner was in person or over the phone. Now, they’re increasingly digital — taking place on dating apps, over text or in direct messages on social media. What were some of the first online words you exchanged with the person you’re with? Do you still have a record of that conversation on your phone or laptop?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Seems Ready to Block a Biden Plan on Air Pollution
description: Several conservative justices were skeptical of the administration’s “good neighbor” rule on cross-state pollution, meant to protect downwind states from harmful emissions.
content: Members of the Supreme Court’s conservative majority seemed inclined on Wednesday to again limit the Biden administration’s ability to protect the environment by temporarily stopping an effort by the Environmental Protection Agency to curtail air pollution that drifts across state lines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $300,000 Homes in Texas, Georgia and Nebraska
description: A two-bedroom cottage in New Braunfels, a one-bedroom condominium in Atlanta and a Craftsman bungalow in Omaha.
content: This house, once part of a church complex, was moved to its current location last year and renovated. New plumbing and electrical systems were installed, and the home was furnished with antique and vintage pieces that are available to buy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: A Brooklyn D.I.Y. Landmark Changes With the Times
description: Less punk. More hyperpop. An anniversary party at the Market Hotel was more about the present than the past.
content: Just before midnight on Saturday, hard techno began pulsating from the Market Hotel, a D.I.Y. music venue located beside the elevated tracks of a Myrtle Avenue subway station in Bushwick, Brooklyn. A crowd of 20-somethings, many of them wearing sunglasses, ripped jeans and fanny packs, lined up in the cold before they threw themselves onto the dance floor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Let Tesla Expand? Germans Vote No.
description: A local town’s vote against the U.S. automaker’s proposed expansion is nonbinding, but citizens expect it to be honored.
content: Residents in the German community where Tesla has its only assembly plant in Europe overwhelming rejected the company’s plan to expand its facilities, dealing a blow to the U.S. automaker and local supporters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Becoming King’ Review: An Actor Marches On
description: This documentary about Ava DuVernay’s 2014 Martin Luther King drama “Selma” plays more like a David Oyelowo tribute than a proper look at the difficulties of making the film.
content: “Becoming King,” a documentary on Paramount+, traces the actor David Oyelowo’s journey to playing the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in Ava DuVernay’s 2014 drama “Selma.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Marino
title: Elliott Erwitt’s Co-op and Photo Studio Are Listed on Central Park West
description: Mr. Erwitt, who died last year, moved to the Brentmore more than 50 years ago. His estate has listed the co-op for $11.5 million and the studio for $2.3 million.
content: Elliott Erwitt had already gained worldwide renown for his memorable photographs of the famous and whimsical when he settled into his grand apartment at 88 Central Park West in the late 1960s.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Met Opera’s New Season: What We Want to See
description: In an effort to program contemporary works, the company will present recent operas by Jeanine Tesori, John Adams, Jake Heggie and Osvaldo Golijov.
content: Contemporary works will be front and center in the coming season, the Metropolitan Opera announced on Wednesday, with four company premieres among its six new productions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz and Nico Grant
title: Google Is Giving Away Some of the A.I. That Powers Chatbots
description: Like Meta, the company opened access to its technology to outside programmers, but kept its most powerful system under wraps.
content: When Meta shared the raw computer code needed to build a chatbot last year, rival companies said Meta was releasing poorly understood and perhaps even dangerous technology into the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch and Dolly Faibyshev
title: An HGTV Star’s Party Inspires a Question: What Makes a Home?
description: While celebrating Jeremiah Brent’s first book, guests pondered the keys to a home, from lighting to artifacts of past lives.
content: What makes a house a home?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Hoberman
title: ‘Lumumba: Death of a Prophet’: Revisiting a Mythic Figure
description: The 1990 documentary about Patrice Lumumba by Raoul Peck (“I Am Not Your Negro”), showing at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, looks and feels newly minted.
content: “If the prophet dies, so does the future,” the director Raoul Peck says early in “Lumumba: Death of a Prophet.” The movie, a personal essay in the form of a history lesson, is as much a poem as it is a documentary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: The Night Owl’s Special: Midnight Spaghetti
description: Sometimes a simple pasta of pantry staples is the best company.
content: I recently moved in with a man. Until now, for the last decade, I lived alone in a shoe-box studio apartment on the north end of Manhattan with my dog, Quentin Compson. Now the man, the dog and I live in a shoe-box one-bedroom in Brooklyn. It took awhile to get used to having another occupy my space, when all I ever had to account for was myself and my wire-haired familiar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Judah
title: The Two-Decade Fight for Two Letters on the Internet
description: The South Pacific island of Niue says it was cheated out of .nu, a domain that turned out to be very lucrative on the other side of the world.
content: The South Pacific island of Niue is one the most remote places in the world. Its closest neighbors, Tonga and American Samoa, are hundreds of miles away. The advent of the internet promised, in a small way, to make Niue and its 2,000 or so residents more connected to the rest of the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: Hope for Suicide Prevention
description: We look at promising, evidence-based efforts to prevent suicide.
content: “The bridge is sealed up.” Last month, with those words, the general manager of the Golden Gate Bridge announced the completion of a suicide barrier — stainless steel netting that extends about 20 feet out from the walkway for the length of the bridge, making a jump into the water below extraordinarily difficult.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: James Biden Tells Republicans His Brother Was Not Involved in Business Deals
description: The president’s younger brother rebutted G.O.P. allegations against Joe Biden in impeachment testimony and portrayed himself as an anchor during family tragedy.
content: When a young Joe Biden embarked on his first political campaign more than 50 years ago, it was his brother Jimmy who dropped out of college and crisscrossed the country to raise money for his bid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Ewen MacIntosh, Comedian on British Sitcom ‘The Office,’ Dies at 50
description: Mr. MacIntosh was known for his role as Keith Bishop, a dry, blunt accountant on the original version of “The Office.”
content: Ewen MacIntosh, a British actor and comedian known for his dry portrayal of Keith Bishop, a lackluster accountant in the acclaimed British sitcom “The Office,” died on Monday in the English town of Darlington. He was 50.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan, Jazmine Ulloa and Maggie Haberman
title: Why Nikki Haley Isn’t Dropping Out
description: She dismissed speculation about her motives behind staying in the race, and has encouraged supporters to stick with her until the end, whenever that may be.
content: When Nikki Haley summoned the national media to Greenville, S.C., on Tuesday, she did something that was strikingly unusual even in this most bizarre of campaigns. She devoted an entire speech to explaining why she was not dropping out of the presidential race.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 21, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Feb. 21, 2024.
content: An article on Saturday about a funeral held for a transgender activist at St. Patrick’s Cathedral misidentified the psalm text that appeared on mass cards under an image of Cecilia Gentili. It is Psalm 23, not Psalm 25.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: The BT Tower, a Once-Futuristic London Landmark, Will Become a Hotel
description: The tower, once used to send telecom traffic, has been sold and will be transformed by the company that turned the TWA terminal at Kennedy Airport into a hotel.
content: St. Paul’s Cathedral, the Tower of London and the London Eye are all important landmarks in Britain’s capital. Yet you can’t spend the night in any of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: For a Rainbow of Color in Winter, Look to the Willow
description: But that’s just the beginning: If you want a living fence or something to feed livestock or material for a natural burial, there’s a willow for you.
content: Want to create a living fence? Or maybe you’d like to produce bountiful harvests of leaves and twigs to feed livestock, or simply enliven a winter landscape with fiery color?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Star Directors Buy Los Angeles Cinema With Plan for ‘Coolest AV Club’
description: Concerned about the future of moviegoing in the filmmaking capital, Jason Reitman and a group of distinguished directors purchased the historic Village Theater in Westwood.
content: With the moviegoing experience under threat from streaming services and ever-improving home entertainment options, a group with a passionate interest in its preservation — three dozen filmmakers who create their works for the big screen, to be enjoyed in the company of large audiences — has decided to do something about it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Trump Again Compares Himself to Navalny While Discussing Legal Woes
description: At a Fox News town hall event, he mentioned his four indictments, which he said were “all because of the fact that I am in politics.”
content: Former President Donald J. Trump continued to liken himself to the Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny during a town hall in South Carolina on Tuesday, at one point directly comparing a civil fraud judgment against him to the case of an anticorruption activist who died in a Russian prison last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Charles Stendig Dies at 99; Introduced Fanciful Furniture From Abroad
description: For nearly two decades he traveled to factories throughout Europe, sometimes behind the Iron Curtain, to bring modern furniture to Americans.
content: Charles Stendig, who introduced contemporary and avant-garde European furniture to adventurous Americans in his New York City showroom, died on Feb. 11 at his home in Manhattan. He was 99.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed Minutes Show Embrace of Inflation Progress but No Hurry to Cut Rates
description: Minutes from the Federal Reserve’s Jan. 30-31 meeting showed policymakers thought that risks of an inflation pickup had “diminished.”
content: Federal Reserve officials welcomed a recent inflation slowdown at their last meeting in late January but were intent on proceeding carefully as they tiptoe toward rate cuts, according to minutes from that gathering, which were released on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanna Biggs
title: A Great Critic Has Died. Here, Her Passions Live On.
description: In a posthumous collection, “The Bloodied Nightgown,” Joan Acocella pays tribute to her many and varied interests.
content: “Art doesn’t start out hallowed,” the New Yorker staff writer Joan Acocella, who died in January at the age of 78, once wrote. “It starts out personal: an emergency.” And so it was for her, one of the best-read, most laconic and least pretentious cultural critics of her generation, from whom we are lucky to have this final volume of collected essays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefanos Chen
title: Poverty Has Soared in New York, With Children Bearing the Brunt
description: The share of New York City residents who could not afford basic essentials jumped dramatically in 2022, with one in four children living in poverty, a new report found.
content: After several years of declining poverty, New York City saw a sharp reversal in 2022, when it experienced its largest yearly increase in the poverty level in a decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Small Businesses Sound Alarm Over Weakening German Economy
description: Thousands of companies, concerned that Germany is facing a recession, are calling for an end to political infighting that has blocked a possible stimulus plan.
content: Thousands of the small and midsize companies that form the backbone of the German economy warned this week that the country was losing its edge, as the country’s central bank signaled the threat of a recession would loom over Germany in the first three months of 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Sella
title: Syria Blames Israel for Deadly Airstrike in Damascus
description: Israel did not comment on the attack, though it has acknowledged hundreds of past strikes on Iran-linked targets in Syria.
content: Syrian state media reported on Wednesday that an airstrike on a residential building in Damascus had killed two people, and said that Israel was responsible for the attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: Beyoncé Becomes First Black Woman to Top Billboard Country Chart
description: Her single “Texas Hold ’Em” debuted atop the country airplay chart after its release during the Super Bowl.
content: Beyoncé’s new country single “Texas Hold ’Em” reached No. 1 on the Billboard country airplay chart this week, making her the first Black female artist to hold the top spot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Japanese Crime Boss Trafficked Nuclear Material From Myanmar, U.S. Says
description: Takeshi Ebisawa, already facing federal drug trafficking charges, offered uranium and plutonium that he expected Iran to use in making nuclear weapons, prosecutors said.
content: A man identified by federal prosecutors as a leader of Japan’s Yakuza organized crime syndicate was charged on Wednesday with trafficking uranium and plutonium from Myanmar with the expectation that Iran would use the material to make nuclear weapons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: The Chips Riding on Nvidia
description: Wall Street is closely watching the semiconductor giant’s earnings report, as questions swirl over its massive stock market valuation on the back of the boom in artificial intelligence.
content: The stock price of the chip giant Nvidia has marched steadily higher over the past year and a half, propelled by investors’ hopes that artificial intelligence is truly transformative technology — and by their hope that the company’s high-end semiconductors will continue to power that technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Duke Shuts Down Huge Plant Collection, Causing Scientific Uproar
description: University officials say they cannot afford to maintain one of the largest herbariums in the United States. Researchers are urging Duke to reconsider.
content: Duke University has decided to close its herbarium, a collection of 825,000 specimens of plants, fungi and algae that was established more than a century ago. The collection, one of the largest and most diverse in the country, has helped scientists map the diversity of plant life and chronicle the impact of humans on the environment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: It’s Never Too Late to Be a Style Influencer
description: Lyn Slater, 70, was deemed the Accidental Icon by a college fashion student. She now has nearly one million followers on social media and is upending notions of aging.
content: “It’s Never Too Late” is a series that tells the stories of people who decide to pursue their dreams on their own terms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur, John Liu and Cade Metz
title: China’s Rush to Dominate A.I. Comes With a Twist: It Depends on U.S. Technology
description: China’s tech firms were caught off guard by breakthroughs in generative artificial intelligence. Beijing’s regulations and a sagging economy aren’t helping.
content: In November, a year after ChatGPT’s release, a relatively unknown Chinese start-up leaped to the top of a leaderboard that judged the abilities of open-source artificial intelligence systems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Nolen
title: War and Illness Could Kill 85,000 Gazans in 6 Months
description: Even under the most optimistic scenario, an immediate cease-fire, an additional 6,500 Gazans could perish, scientists estimated.
content: An escalation of the war in Gaza could lead to the deaths of 85,000 Palestinians from injuries and disease over the next six months, in the worst of three situations that prominent epidemiologists have modeled in an effort to understand the potential future death toll of the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Martin, Julia Botero, Christina Djossa, Reva Goldberg, Emily Lang, Jen Poyant, Daniel Ramirez, Astead W. Herndon, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Pat McCusker, Diane Wong and Elisheba Ittoop
title: A Politics Reporter Walks Into a Singles Mixer
description: Politics and speed dating: What could go wrong? Astead Herndon, host of “The Run-Up,” talks to Anna Martin about his recent reporting excursion.
content: The New York Times political reporter Astead Herndon went speed dating in a swing state to ask daters fun questions like: How early do you tell a prospective date whether you lean red or blue? When do you talk about your stances on issues like abortion or gender equality? It’s hard enough to find someone you click with. Then add election-year tensions into the mix, and things get even more complicated.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Rethinking How We Fund the Arts in America
description: Responses to an essay that suggested treating cultural spaces like infrastructure. Also: U.S. Steel; immigration; a no-victims defense; a shadow government.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: Alabama Says Embryos in a Lab Are Children. What Are the Implications?
description: A ruling by the state’s Supreme Court could change common practices at fertility clinics in the state and possibly nationwide.
content: The Alabama Supreme Court has opened a new front in the legal debate over when human life begins. Embryos created and stored in a medical facility must be considered children under the state’s law governing harmful death, the court ruled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liesl Schillinger
title: The Affair That Split New York High Society
description: In “Strong Passions,” the historian Barbara Weisberg tells the story of an explosive, lurid 1860s case that still resonates today.
content: The touch of a hand from two centuries ago can spark powerful emotions in the present. Just ask any of the TikTok romantics who swoon over the passionate hand flex in the 2005 adaptation of “Pride and Prejudice” — Mr. Darcy’s reaction to clasping Lizzy Bennet’s palm for the first time. In Jane Austen’s novel, their chemistry leads to marriage and the elevation of the heroine’s fortunes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: U.S. Warns Allies Russia Could Put a Nuclear Weapon Into Orbit This Year
description: The American assessments are divided, however, and President Vladimir Putin denied having such an intention, saying that Russia was “categorically against” it.
content: American intelligence agencies have told their closest European allies that if Russia is going to launch a nuclear weapon into orbit, it will probably do so this year — but that it might instead launch a harmless “dummy” warhead into orbit to leave the West guessing about its capabilities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: Study of Patients With a Chronic Fatigue Condition May Offer Clues to Long Covid
description: N.I.H. researchers found notable differences between the immune systems and other physiological functions of patients with ME/CFS and those of healthy patients.
content: Jennifer Caldwell was active and energetic, working two jobs and taking care of her daughter and her parents, when she developed a bacterial infection that was followed by intense lightheadedness, fatigue and memory problems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: I.R.S. to Crack Down on Corporate Jet Users Who Abuse Tax Code
description: The tax collection agency’s scrutiny will involve new data analytics tools to find private jet owners who claim millions of dollars in deductions on planes being used for personal travel.
content: The Internal Revenue Service said on Wednesday that it would begin cracking down on corporate jet owners that abused the tax code by claiming millions of dollars in deductions on airplanes that were sometimes being used for personal travel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryn Stole
title: A Film Festival in the Back of a Taxi
description: The TaxiFilmFest is partly a protest over the miserable state of Berlin’s taxi industry. But it’s also a celebration of the cab’s iconic place in the urban cultural landscape.
content: Some of international cinema’s biggest names gathered on Tuesday night at the Berlin International Film Festival as the event honored Martin Scorsese with a lifetime achievement award. Before accepting his trophy, Scorsese listened as the German director Wim Wenders gave a laudatory speech to an audience including celebrities and local dignitaries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: Does Biden Have to Cede the White Working Class to Trump?
description: Democratic strategists are asking whether the president’s attempt to recapture these voters is a fool’s errand.
content: A chorus of political analysts on the center left is once again arguing that the Democratic Party must reclaim a significant share of racially and culturally conservative white working-class voters if it is to regain majority status.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: 6 Objects That Explain New Rules on Native Displays in Museums
description: A look at how the Field Museum in Chicago is responding to recent federal regulations that have led officials to cover objects they may need to return to tribes.
content: When new federal regulations took effect last month requiring museums to get consent from tribes before exhibiting certain Native cultural items, museums across the country began to remove objects from cases, cover up displays and even close entire halls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy
title: As U. of Arizona Confronts Budget Cuts, Workers and Students Brace for the Worst
description: The public university, the largest employer in the Tucson area, says it’s facing a $177 million shortfall. Critics worry that lower-tier workers and Arizona students will be hit hardest by efforts to cut back.
content: Like thousands of people in southern Arizona, Josh Ramos’s fate is intertwined with the University of Arizona. His mother’s job as a university accountant supports the family, and Mr. Ramos’s education, by qualifying him for a discount that cuts his tuition by 75 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: Arizona Refuses to Send Murder Suspect to New York Over Bragg’s Policies
description: The Maricopa County attorney in Arizona said she would fight to keep a man who authorities believe bludgeoned a woman to death in a New York City hotel.
content: On Feb. 8, a woman was found dead in a Manhattan hotel room, bludgeoned to death with an iron.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin and Azeen Ghorayshi
title: Alabama Rules Frozen Embryos Are Children, Raising Questions About Fertility Care
description: The ruling raises worrisome legal issues for would-be parents far beyond Alabama whose hopes for children may depend on in vitro fertilization.
content: An Alabama Supreme Court’s ruling that frozen embryos in test tubes should be considered children has sent shock waves through the world of reproductive medicine, casting doubt over fertility care for would-be parents in the state and raising complex legal questions with implications extending far beyond Alabama.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mireille Silcoff
title: Teen Subcultures Are Fading. Pity the Poor Kids.
description: Gorgeous, abundant visuals are just pale imitations of what young people used to have: an actual scene.
content: A few weeks ago, my 12-year-old daughter showed me a video created by a Dallas clothing store called Dear Hannah Prep, depicting a girl’s first time visiting “the preppiest boutique in Texas.” “How excited are you?” an off-camera voice asks. “I’m so excited!” the girl says. Then she opens the door, gasps and declares, “It’s so preppy in here!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiba Yazbek
title: Israeli Raid in West Bank City of Jenin Kills 3, Military Says
description: The Israeli military said its latest deadly raid targeted “terrorism” and was part of a broader operation in the Israeli-occupied territory.
content: Israeli forces killed three people and detained at least 14 others in an overnight raid in the West Bank city of Jenin, the Israeli military said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juan A. Ramírez
title: ‘Sunset Baby’ Review: Don’t Let Nina Be Misunderstood
description: Moses Ingram makes her New York stage debut in Dominique Morisseau’s love poem to Nina Simone.
content: Dominique Morisseau’s characters are, as the post-colonial thinker Frantz Fanon once described himself, often paralyzed “at the crossroads between nothingness and infinity.” Her plays craft realistic depictions of marginalized people inextricably caught in the tide of history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: BuzzFeed Sells Complex, a Pop Culture Start-Up, for $108.6 Million
description: The digital-media company, which has plunged in value, is selling the unit to Ntwrk at a significant discount from its 2021 purchase price.
content: BuzzFeed said on Wednesday that it was selling Complex — a media start-up known for its coverage of streetwear and pop culture — at a significant discount from its purchase price.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Why Does the Right to Protest Matter?
description: Aleksei Navalny, the Russian opposition leader, died in a prison last week. Many of his supporters have been arrested. Why does this matter — for Russia and the world?
content: For more than a decade, the anticorruption activist Aleksei A. Navalny was the leader of the opposition in President Vladimir V. Putin’s Russia. In 2020, Mr. Navalny survived a near-fatal poisoning attempt widely blamed on the Kremlin. After recovering in Germany, Mr. Navalny returned to Russia in 2021, and he was immediately arrested.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Rogers
title: A Top Oscar Nominee, Uneasy in the Spotlight
description: A best actress nomination changes everything — Sandra Hüller knows that. She just isn’t sure that’s a good thing.
content: After Sandra Hüller learned that two movies she stars in — “Anatomy of a Fall” and “The Zone of Interest” — had been selected for the competition at last year’s Cannes Film Festival, she was a little apprehensive about what it might mean for her anonymity. The German actress has always had a prickly relationship with fame: Aside from her role in the bittersweet 2016 feature “Toni Erdmann,” she has mainly kept a low profile, working in German theater.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shayla Martin
title: 2 Black Heroes, 2 Cities in New York: A Journey Into the Past
description: On a snowy trip to Rochester and Auburn, N.Y., a writer explores the cities that Frederick Douglass and Harriet Tubman called home.
content: Memphis. Atlanta. Birmingham. There are certain American cities that are known for Black history. But African American history and culture can, of course, be found across the United States, in seemingly unlikely cities, like Portland, Maine, say, or Providence, R.I.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Harold Goldberg
title: Game Reviews: A Psychedelic Adventure and a Tedious Drive
description: The visual flourishes and floral secrets in Ultros make its claustrophobic passageways inviting. But keeping your vehicle roadworthy in Pacific Drive is too much work.
content: Beyond blockbuster video games is a world of original ideas from smaller studios. We’ll regularly highlight some of the newer options.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Jeff Bezos’s Big Rocket Moves Into View and Closer to Launch
description: Blue Origin’s New Glenn rocket rolled to the launchpad for a series of tests in preparation for its flight debut later this year.
content: There’s an easy knock against the space dreams of Jeff Bezos and his rocket company, Blue Origin: In its 24th year of existence, the company has yet to launch a single thing to orbit.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Live Performance in New York: Here’s What to See This Spring
description: “The Notebook” and “Cabaret” land on Broadway. Olivia Rodrigo’s tour stops in Manhattan. Plus: Herbie Hancock, Heartbeat Opera and Trisha Brown Dance Company.
content: THE NOTEBOOK Nicholas Sparks’s 1996 novel (adapted for the screen in 2004) is now a sweeping musical tale of romantic idealism and the decades-long love between Allie and Noah. The Chicago Tribune gave a glowing review to the 2022 Chicago Shakespeare Theater premiere, and several performers from the Chicago cast, including Maryann Plunkett as Older Allie, will reprise their roles. The show features a book by Bekah Brunstetter (“This Is Us”) and music and lyrics by Ingrid Michaelson, with Michael Greif and Schele Williams directing. Now playing at the Schoenfeld Theater, Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Oregon Tries and Fails to Eliminate Daylight Saving Time, for Now
description: Also, did you know Oregon has two time zones?
content: Oregon’s state senate failed to advance a bill on Tuesday that would have abolished daylight saving time in most of the state and switched it to standard time for the entire year, the latest chapter in an effort by states to settle on whether clocks need to fall back or spring forward at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Are We in a Productivity Boom? For Clues, Look to 1994.
description: Thirty years ago, the U.S. entered an era of productivity gains that enabled healthy growth. Experts are asking if it could happen again.
content: The last time the American economy was posting surprising economic growth numbers amid rapid wage gains and moderating inflation, Ace of Base and All-4-One topped the Billboard charts and denim overalls were in vogue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Here’s How an Open Democratic Convention Would Work
description: Elaine Kamarck breaks down the presidential nomination process.
content: [You can listen to this episode of “The Ezra Klein Show” on the NYT Audio App, Apple, Spotify, Amazon Music, Google or wherever you get your podcasts.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Danielle Brooks Has an Oscar Nomination. So Why Is She in Mourning?
description: As she tries to find her place in Hollywood, the “Color Purple” stage and screen star bids an emotional goodbye to a character she has lived with for nearly a decade.
content: Was it an interview or an unburdening? As she wiped away tears, Danielle Brooks confessed she couldn’t tell the difference.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas and Edward Wong
title: Brazil, in Dispute with Israel, Shows Limits of U.S. Diplomacy
description: Israel and Brazil have sparred this week over the Gaza war. Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken intervened on Wednesday.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken confronted President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil on Wednesday about his recent sharp comments on Israel, including the Brazilian leader’s comparison of Israel’s attacks in Gaza to the Holocaust.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: If Garfield Made Soup, He’d Make This Soup
description: All the flavors and comfort of a classic lasagna in an easy, one-pot weeknight dinner.
content: Of all the wildly popular American takes on Italian cuisine (spaghetti and meatballs; fettuccine Alfredo; chicken Parmesan), the latest to go viral is lasagna soup, thanks to one TikTok user with a Lego set and a thing for pasta. Christina Morales got the whole story for The New York Times, and naturally we have the recipe. It retains everything you love about lasagna — the tomatoey marinara, spicy Italian sausage, soft sheets of pasta and milky ricotta cheese — and simmers it together with chicken stock to create the red sauced comfort food of your dreams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: A Fight to Preserve a Pristine Piece of Old New York
description: The director of the Merchant’s House Museum in the East Village, a rowhouse that is 192 years old, is worried about a plan to construct a new building next door.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll look at why a museum is at odds with the city, which owns the 192-year-old rowhouse it occupies. We’ll also look at a class-action lawsuit that accuses the agency responsible for investigating child abuse of using “coercive tactics” that traumatize families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Home Depot Is Ordered to Reinstate Worker Who Quit Over ‘BLM’ Logo
description: The National Labor Relations Board said that Home Depot violated federal law in 2021 when it told a worker that they must quit or stop showing support for the Black Lives Matter movement on their apron.
content: Home Depot must reinstate a worker who quit after they refused to remove a slogan supporting the Black Lives Matter movement from their apron, the National Labor Relations Board announced on Wednesday after it found that the worker’s actions were protected by federal law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa and Maya King
title: Why Black Democrats Are Unlikely to Aid Haley in South Carolina
description: Nikki Haley could use crossover support in her fight against Donald Trump, but she has alienated the Black voters who are central to the state’s Democratic voting base.
content: It appeared to be Nikki Haley’s most diverse audience yet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Alabama Hospital Paused I.V.F. Treatments After Court Ruling
description: Also, President Biden canceled $1.2 billion in student loan debt. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: The University of Alabama at Birmingham health system, which includes the state’s largest hospital, announced today that it would pause in vitro fertilization treatments after the Alabama Supreme Court ruled that frozen embryos in test tubes should be considered children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: A Voracious Black Hole at the Dawn of Time?
description: Scientists debate whether this object is the brightest in the visible universe, as a new study suggests.
content: Astronomers claimed on Monday that they had discovered what might be the hungriest, most luminous object in the visible universe — a supermassive black hole that was swallowing a star a day. That would be the mass equivalent of 370 suns a year disappearing down a cosmic gullet 11 billion years ago at the dawn of time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Sella
title: Israeli Rape-Crisis Group Report Finds ‘Systematic’ Sexual Violence on and After Oct. 7
description: Israeli activists and their allies have expressed frustration at international organizations like the United Nations for slow responses to such reports.
content: An Israeli organization that supports survivors of sexual abuse released a report on Wednesday concluding that acts of sexual violence against Israelis during and after the Hamas-led attack on Oct. 7 were “systematic and widespread.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: How Biden Can Avenge Navalny’s Death
description: The president cannot allow Russia’s rulers to think that his threats are hollow.
content: President Biden said last week that he was “looking at a whole number of options” to make good on his 2021 warning to Vladimir Putin that Russia would face “devastating” consequences if Aleksei Navalny were to die in prison. Now that Putin has treated that warning with his customary contempt, Biden needs to act as a matter of moral clarity and personal credibility, and for the strategic imperative of demonstrating to a dictator that American threats aren’t hollow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adelle Waldman and Vishakha Darbha
title: I Worked at a Big-Box Store. Here’s a Way to Improve the Lives of Low-Wage Workers.
description: Adelle Waldman on why a certain corporate loophole needs tightening.
content: One of the lesser-known problems facing many low-wage workers in America is unpredictable and scarce work hours — something the writer Adelle Waldman knows firsthand. She worked at a big-box store for six months to research her latest novel, about a group of employees plotting to overthrow their bad boss. In this audio essay, Waldman explains how her experience exposed her to the way inflexible hours can wreak havoc in people’s lives, from lack of health insurance to the inability to pick up a second job.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Becoming the New Face Opposing the Kremlin
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, February 21, 2024.
content: “Putin killed half of me, half of my heart and half of my soul. But I have another half left — and it is telling me I have no right to give up.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Covering the Rise of Tracy Chapman
description: In 1988, “Fast Car” turned the singer-songwriter into a star. She was skeptical of the spotlight, and learning to wield her power.
content: Tracy Chapman’s ascent to the pop stratosphere in 1988 was not in any way guaranteed. She was making folk music in a time of stadium rock and hip-hop. She was orienting her songs around social concerns. And yet, after a few fortuitous turns in the summer of that year, Chapman’s “Fast Car” became a global anthem. And its success landed her on the cover of Rolling Stone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angelo Fichera
title: Fact-Checking Biden’s Recent Economic Talking Points
description: President Biden has made some misleading statements during campaign and public events in recent weeks as he discussed taxes, industry, jobs and more.
content: As he seeks re-election, President Biden has been trying to sell voters on his approach to the economy and draw a contrast with his likely 2024 opponent, former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Anjali Huynh
title: Protesting Biden, Gaza Supporters Warn, ‘Don’t Blame Us’ if You Lose
description: At the University of Michigan, a demonstration against President Biden’s stance on Israel showed his critics’ passion but was light on numbers.
content: About 100 people turned out on Tuesday at the University of Michigan to urge Democrats to reject President Biden in the state’s primary election, a political gathering that illustrated both the passion and the limits of the effort to pressure him into calling for Israel to stop waging war in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martha Schwendener
title: When Zines Walked the Earth
description: An extraordinary exhibition of dissident and countercultural takes at the Brooklyn Museum shows the power of the copy machine.
content: Before the internet, before the spicy comments sections on Instagram and Twitter or the outré subcultures on TikTok, like-minded strangers connected through zines. What is a zine?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: U.S. Moon Landing: How to Watch and What to Know
description: If all goes as planned, Odysseus, a private spacecraft, will touch down on the lunar surface on Thursday. It will be the first U.S. moon landing in more than 50 years.
content: On Wednesday morning, a robotic lunar lander launched by a Houston company got closer to reaching the moon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman and Edgar Sandoval
title: Anti-Trans Policies Draw Scrutiny After 16-Year-Old’s Death in Oklahoma
description: The student, who did not identify as male or female, according to their family, died a day after an altercation in a school bathroom. The police said the death was not a result of trauma.
content: A 16-year-old student in a small Oklahoma town outside Tulsa died after what the police said was a “physical altercation” in a high school bathroom, drawing outrage from gay and transgender rights groups who said the student was attacked because of their gender identity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib, Annie Correal and Jack Nicas
title: In Latin America, Guards Don’t Control Prisons, Gangs Do
description: Intended to fight crime, Latin American prisons have instead become safe havens and recruitment centers for gangs, fueling a surge in violence.
content: Ecuador’s military was sent in to seize control of the country’s prisons last month after two major gang leaders escaped and criminal groups quickly set off a nationwide revolt that paralyzed the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: My Brother’s Ex-Wife Won’t Return a Family Heirloom. Help!
description: A reader had hoped that her grandmother’s ring would stay in the family, perhaps to pass on to her daughter, but her former sister-in-law has so far refused to give it back.
content: When my brother got engaged, he gave his fiancée — with my blessing — a ring that is a family heirloom. It belonged to our grandmother, who died before we were born. It didn’t occur to me that the ring was possibly leaving our family, which is what happened when they later divorced. My brother asked his ex-wife if she would return the ring, but she refused. I’ve tried to let this go: It’s just an object and not worth a lot of money, but I still harbor hard feelings. I was fond of my former sister-in-law; she was sweet to me and my kids. But we don’t have many things that belonged to my grandparents, and I’d rather give the ring to my daughter than let a stranger hang on to it. (My brother’s ex-wife doesn’t have children.) May I ask for it back?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: What to Know About This Crazily Crowded Broadway Spring Season
description: Why are 18 shows opening in March and April, and which one is for you? Our theater reporter has answers.
content: Is Broadway facing a bonanza or a blood bath?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Ex-President Made Honduras a Safe Haven for Drug Gangs, Prosecutors Say
description: The former president, Juan Orlando Hernández, went on trial Wednesday in Manhattan, accused of years of misrule funded by cocaine proceeds.
content: Brick after brick of cocaine flowed for years into the United States from countries like Venezuela and Colombia, all of it funneled through the tiny Central American nation of Honduras.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Cramer and Jonathan D. Cohen
title: Many Americans Believe the Economy Is Rigged
description: The economy is driven by greed and shot with uncertainty. That’s what Americans said in more than 30 small-group discussions in the past two years.
content: When asked what drives the economy, many Americans have a simple, single answer that comes to mind immediately: “greed.” They believe the rich and powerful have designed the economy to benefit themselves and have left others with too little or with nothing at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Kenji López-Alt
title: Why Do Some Things Freeze Better Than Others?
description: In his new column, Ask Kenji, the cookbook author Kenji López-Alt answers your questions. First up: why smaller is better in the freezer.
content: Welcome to my new column, Ask Kenji. I’ve spent the last decade and a half of my career rigorously researching and testing recipes, techniques and widely accepted kitchen wisdom to figure out the whys of cooking. I’ll try to answer the questions you’d answer yourself — if you had the resources and time, diving into research, tapping writers, chefs and scientists, and designing kitchen experiments to get to the bottom of your burning cooking questions. This week, we look at a reader question and figure out why, when it comes to the freezer, smaller (and faster) is better.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: forsake
description: This word has appeared in 26 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word forsake has appeared in 26 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 22 in the Opinion essay “The Most Common Graduation Advice Tends to Backfire” by Sapna Cheryan and Therese Anne Mortejo:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Our 11th Annual 15-Second Vocabulary Video Challenge
description: We invite students to create a short video that defines or teaches one of our recent Words of the Day. Contest dates: Feb. 28-March 27, 2024.
content: Do you love the magic of words? Do you enjoy showing off your vocabulary — or finding new ways to expand it? And do you appreciate brevity — keeping things short and sweet?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Friskics-Warren
title: Jimmy Van Eaton, Purveyor of the Sun Records Beat, Dies at 86
description: His drumming lent spontaneity and imagination to the unfettered sound of seminal rock ’n’ roll records by Jerry Lee Lewis and others.
content: Jimmy Van Eaton, who played drums on epoch-defining hits, including Jerry Lee Lewis’s “Great Balls of Fire” and “Whole Lotta Shakin’ Goin’ On,” and lent spontaneity and imagination to the unfettered sound of the influential Memphis label Sun Records, died on Feb. 9 at his home in Tuscumbia, Ala. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Biden Hardens Protection Against Cybersecurity Threats to Ports
description: An executive order expands powers to the Department of Homeland Security amid increased fears of a conflict with China.
content: President Biden signed an executive order on Wednesday to strengthen the government’s ability to respond to maritime cybersecurity threats, amid heightened concerns that China could seek to hobble crucial infrastructure systems in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Ban Fossil Fuels? Readers Had Strong Thoughts.
description: Some lauded the idea. Others said it would play into OPEC’s hands.
content: I got a lot of responses to my Friday newsletter on restricting the supply of fossil fuels, one of which said “oof no” in the subject line. It was from an economist named Benjamin Ho, who wrote that he usually likes my newsletter, “But, oh boy, was today’s off track.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum
title: An Election Shatters the Image of Pakistan’s Mightiest Force
description: Pakistanis once thought of the military as the iron hand controlling the country’s politics. That illusion has been broken, creating one of the establishment’s biggest crises yet.
content: The intimidating myth of an all-powerful military in Pakistan has been smashed in public view.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold, Steven Erlanger, Eric Krupke, Olivia Natt, Mooj Zadie, Marc Georges, M.J. Davis Lin, Devon Taylor, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop and Alyssa Moxley
title: What Happens if America Turns Its Back on Its Allies in Europe
description: Faltering U.S. support for Ukraine and comments from Donald Trump about NATO have caused alarm in European capitals.
content: Over the past few weeks, a growing sense of alarm across Europe over the future of the continent’s security has turned into outright panic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: Over 60, Single and Never Happier
description: Why some older people who have given up looking for romantic love say they feel self-assured and satisfied on their own.
content: Joy Lorton, 80, has been married and divorced four times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Golembiewski
title: These Whales Still Use Their Vocal Cords. But How?
description: Unusual experiments on organs recovered from three carcasses suggest how baleen whales call out at sea.
content: People have told stories of strange underwater sounds for thousands of years, but it took until the mid-20th century for scientists to pinpoint one of the causes: whales, singing and whistling and squeaking in the blue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: ‘Wild’ Ice Skating
description: Each winter, adventurous skaters head to the frozen lakes of Alaska for wild ice skating. What’s your favorite outdoor thrill?
content: Elaine Glusac, the Times Frugal Traveler columnist, chronicled her adventures last year wild skating — outdoor skating on naturally formed ice — on the pristine frozen lakes of southern Alaska, with 10-story glaciers looming above her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Suhasini Raj and John Yoon
title: Ameen Sayani, Pioneering Radio Star in India, Dies at 91
description: One of the first voices heard on the airwaves in Asia, he became recognized by generations of listeners in India over 42 years of broadcasting Bollywood music.
content: Ameen Sayani, a pioneering radio presenter who drew in generations of listeners in India with his melodic voice on a radio show that became a national phenomenon, died in Mumbai on Tuesday. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Kenneth P. Vogel
title: The Informant Turned Defendant Who Took Aim at the Bidens
description: How Alexander Smirnov managed to convince business partners, law enforcement agencies and politicians he had something of value to offer remains an enigma.
content: Alexander Smirnov was, in many ways, the archetype of an informant operating in the shadowlands of the former Soviet Union — a profiteer, fixer and gossip who promoted his ability to make sense of a confusing landscape to American law enforcement agencies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.J. Goldmann
title: ‘Poor Things,’ the Weird Movie, Was a Weird Novel First
description: The Oscar-nominated film is based on a 1992 book by the prolific Scotsman Alasdair Gray. Beloved by writers, “that’s not the same as being widely read,” says one of them.
content: Hot air balloons soar above the Mediterranean. Aerial streetcars fly along ropes suspended above the alleys of a candy-colored Lisbon. Pastel green smoke billows into the night sky from the funnels of a cruise ship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric A. Taub
title: Renting a Car Abroad: Don’t Get Taken for a Ride
description: Hitting the open road can be a memorable way to explore a country, but it comes with potentially expensive hazards. Here’s how to navigate some of them.
content: “Throw the keys through the kiosk’s open window. We’ll get the car when we open later”: Those slightly unorthodox drop-off instructions I once received from a Hertz manager in Croatia illustrate some of the differences U.S. travelers might encounter when renting a car abroad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: A Russian Military Blogger Dies After Criticizing Army Losses
description: The ultranationalist blogger, Andrei Morozov, had described a campaign of intimidation against him and threatened to end his own life.
content: A pro-war Russian military blogger died on Wednesday, his lawyer said, after the blogger wrote the country’s military pressured him to remove a post exposing the scale of its losses in a recent battle in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Woman Sues Tomato Company, Saying Those Weren’t San Marzanos in the Can
description: A federal judge said the lawsuit, in which a California woman accused Simpson Imports of using “highly misleading” packaging, could proceed. The company says its labels do not call the product “San Marzano.”
content: San Marzano tomatoes are prized by chefs around the world for their intense flavor and are routinely recommended by recipe writers, but one woman in California said that her effort to make a sauce from these rich and balanced tomatoes was upset by a misleading label.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: What’s in Our Queue? Thandiswa Mazwai and More
description: I’m a reporter for The New York Times based in Johannesburg. Here are five things I’ve been enjoying.
content: I’m a reporter for The New York Times based in Johannesburg. Here are five things I’ve been enjoying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by Michael Gonchar
title: How Much Do You Know About St. Lucia?
description: Can you find St. Lucia on a map? What else do you know about this Caribbean island nation with about 180,000 people?
content: Can you find St. Lucia on a map? What else do you know about this Caribbean island nation with about 180,000 people?
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Life Without a Home
description: Voices from the tents, shelters, cars, motels and couches of America.
content: Voices from the tents, shelters, cars, motels and couches of America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small, Gabriel Blanco and Rebecca Suner
title: How Final Fantasy VII Changed the Gaming Landscape
description: Final Fantasy VII, one of the most consequential games in history, is being remade by its creators. Zachary Small, a reporter for The New York Times, breaks down the characters, world and it’s impact.
content: Final Fantasy VII, one of the most consequential games in history, is being remade by its creators. Zachary Small, a reporter for The New York Times, breaks down the characters, world and it’s impact.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Hanley, Claire Hogan and Jeanna Smialek
title: How Productivity Affects the Economy
description: Thirty years ago, the U.S. entered an era of productivity gains that enabled healthy growth. Experts are asking if it could happen again.
content: Thirty years ago, the U.S. entered an era of productivity gains that enabled healthy growth. Experts are asking if it could happen again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikolay Nikolov and Christina Goldbaum
title: How an Election Shattered the Image of Pakistan’s Military
description: Pakistanis once thought of the military as the iron hand controlling the country’s politics. That illusion has been broken following a contested election in early February, creating one of the establishment’s biggest crises yet.
content: Pakistanis once thought of the military as the iron hand controlling the country’s politics. That illusion has been broken following a contested election in early February, creating one of the establishment’s biggest crises yet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Deadly Airstrike Hits Neighborhood in Damascus, Syria
description: Syrian state media blamed the strike, which it said had killed two people, on Israel. The Israeli military declined to comment.
content: Syrian state media blamed the strike, which it said had killed two people, on Israel. The Israeli military declined to comment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: U.S. Defends Israeli Occupation of Palestinian Territories
description: The United States urged the International Court of Justice not to call for immediate withdrawal of Israel from Palestinian territories, and to consider the country’s security needs.
content: The United States urged the International Court of Justice not to call for immediate withdrawal of Israel from Palestinian territories, and to consider the country’s security needs.
source.name: The New York Times
